Statement: People and their demands are ever growing but theavailability of land is limited
The thin layer of grainy substance covering the surface of the earth is called soil
The major factors of soil formation are the nature of the parent rock and climatic factors.
Factors which lead to soil degradation are deforestation, overgrazing, overuse of chemical feritilisers or pesticides, rain wash, landslides and floods.
Nearly 70 per cent of this occurs as ice sheets and glaciers in Antarctica, Greenland and mountain regions.
Forest and other vegetation cover slow the surface runoff and replenish underground water
Changes of technology and human interferences can cause the loss of natural habitats for the plants and animals.
In Intercropping, different crops are grown in one field and are sown at different times to protect the soil from rain wash
Soil stress and depletion are the major threats to soil as a resource.
The use of land is determined by physical factors such as fertile soil, climate, minerals and availability of water.
